reviewText:
This game has bugs and it does have features that weren't the smartest move since Shogun 2; however, the game has a fun factor that trumps all of its downfalls.

CA implemented certain features in this total war game that will make it harder to play older TW games, and they did in fact put in more beneficial and simpler features than poorly implemented ones.  The game suffers from AI problems and other misc bugs, and I feel it's not nearly as polished as Shogun 2 (one of the most polished TW games after expansions/patching imo), but it has a way better campaign, factions, unit rosters, building/culture rosters, and other features that make it a lot more fun than Shogun 2.

I wrote a positive review about Shogun 2 before, claiming it to be the best TW game released ever, and while that's true for the most polished and bug-free total war ever, I feel that Rome 2 will become the better game if it continue to be patched positively.

So in summary, I feel Shogun 2 is the better polished and bug-free game.  Rome 2 is the more fun game and better campaign with more interesting units.  It just needs help to improve and polish it.

reviewText:
This is probably the only review I've given for a game, and I've done so because I've never felt so ripped off in my life for buying this over-hyped POS.

I'll start the slow clap to CA for the fantastic marketing of this game. I've played since Medieval I, and was blown away with Rome I when it first came out. I think CA knew that a majority of their players felt the same way, and made Rome II to be something much more grander than the original with their siege of Carthage video and the new Rally Point teasers. I pre-ordered...and CA played me well I'll give them that.

I played through all the patches, but I think it's safe for all of the players to assume that nothing CA can do will bring back the immersion and strategy that the prior TW games brought to the table. I swear to you, I've never even bothered to look at the general's traits because they don't matter. They die before they become significant. All that matters is grinding them to commander, general, infantry commander II, and great leader and bringing them to your training" Providences to pump out level III gold units for the rest of your armies so that you can steam roll the AI. Rinse and repeat. I've played many factions
date: and every time Rome is annihilated very early before I can even fight them...in a game called Rome II. Seige AI? Ha...just send out your useless plebs to attack their ladder units
recommended: and then slaughter the rest of the army at your gates when they abandon their ladders. Battles? Just use your infantry line to hold the enemy (after you take their skirmishers out with your calvary) while your javelin units get at least 200+ kills and eventually lead to the route of the enemy unit. No real strategy at all. You can use a different faction
hoursPlayed: but the same strategy always works. You can't lose unless you purposely try to. The series has been dumbed down beyond belief.\n\nThis is probably the only time I felt like I was scammed into buying a game based on past reputation and hype. CA

reviewText:
The game (for me) is quite good to play.

The constant updates are quite nice, (for bug fixes) but really nearly 12 months after it first came out these should be sorted. Also there has been absolutely no real changes, since about December, and this is frustrating as the patches are large and (therefore take a long time to download) but often offer no real change unless the last patch had screwed up your game up and the new one may now correct it.

Also although worth buying (on sale), the DLC do not add much to the game apart from widening the very limited vanilla faction range or unit roster. You would have thought that having screwed the game up, they might have given units such as war dogs (present in Rome 1) to the poor people who have bought the game and put up with all the problems (and not charged them to expand the factions by three from the meagre 9 or so at the start).

Having derided the DLC in the section above, I must admit that the two campaigns are nice to play (on sale). (Out of choice go for the one with Hannibal, as it offers more variation in the opponents- Gauls, Africans, Italians, Carthage... etc.)

[THEY ARE GREEDY] You just have to make sure anything you buy, including the game itself, is only ever on sale so as not to feed them so much money.

The game itself isn't really that bad, it just didn't live up to all the hype and this has led to a bad feeling running through the community.

I would recommend it for any who like the total war series but I implore you to not expect much.

reviewerDisplayName: video games are bad for you
reviewText:
This game was too glitchy at launch, I have had my fun with this but the glitchiness I have expereinced is sometimes annoying. The AI is just stupid, and too passive if you ask me. I would like if if the other nations would be more colorful like in Total War: Shogun II. By more colorful I mean the nations wouldn't just be Friendy, Passive and Aggresive. There were more shades to how they reacted to what you did. Also the AI's combat is terrible, watch as your neat perfect assault formation gets ruined the second you hit the enemy. Once your formation is ruined all the people group up in a horrible moshpitty blob. I have played a lot of co-op in this, it's passible but didn't bring much to the table from Shogun II. Honestly I could go on and on about how Shogun II was better gameplay-wise and how it is a finished game, so you can tell that I reccomend Shogun II over Rome II as it is finished and it's just more fun in my oppinion.

P.S.; I have 40 more hours of gameplay on Shogun II than Rome II (Shogun: 121 hours, Rome: 81 hours)

7/10

reviewText: This game is awesome. All of the people who say it was terrible were the people that rushed CA so they had to release rome II early, unfinished, as they still worked on the game. Then the people said the game was crap. Well you rushed them and made them release an unfinished game! Next, the patches covered up almost all glitches, but ones like after a character ranks up they turn grey indefinatly, or the character rank often doesn't show are still remaining, but almost all are gone, and people are STILL complaining. And even the people that do hate it have played 300 hours of it, and posted about 10 youtube videos of them playing it. And yes, they removed the family tree, that sucks, but there are so many new features! Like how people need attention, or recruiting mercenaries,  which all are just awesome! Anyone who hates this game just seems like a 5 year old supporting his opinion even though he has been proved wrong.

reviewText:
3 Months ago i noticed this game in the store,and due to the high price and the AWFUL Critic and Players reviews i thought it was not a great game,from the first time i found it awesome,but i tought it was only because i completely love the Roman and Ellenic Culture. After some time i decided to buy it. OH BOY,the result was amazing. INCREDIBLE GRAPHIC,Processor doesent count (Not SO much).. an Intel Core i3 Like mine is more than ok,Graphic Card got to be awesome in order to play the game,i got a Ge Force Nvidia GT 540M with 2GB Memory,and 4 GB Ram. Game still Lags on some points,but nothing is perfect.
Game,strategy,personalization,EVERYTHING is perfect.
The Only 2 Negative Points
1 You need a NASA PC to play this without any lag or issue
2 AI is totally crappy in some points of the game,and better than Caesar,Annibal and Dr. evil Together in others. In a strange point,while defending,my soldiers were around 400,enemies around 2000. They stopped in the Arrow dropping point without moving. After 15 Minutes all the units ran away from the battlefield. Wow. Anyway,i got to say it is worth 60$ if you can pay more for COD or BF,well this is worth 100$.

reviewText: Absolutely love this game. It had a really bad release, full of bugs and unforgiveable idiocy, but the patches have really fixed up the game and it runs like a charm. No doubt it's a bit of a system hog (especially on the highest graphics settings), but the beautiful scenes when two units clash, how javelins actually stick into the units they hit, these all add wonderful effects to the game and really immerse you in your battles.\n\nUnofrtunately, Shogun 2 is far superior in terms of the graphics, in my opinion. Regardless, the gameplay in Rome 2 is superb, especially in multiplayer. I've sunk hours into playing with friends, combatting eachother, even playing as the AI during their battles to make things that little bit harder for them! I would recommend this game to anyone, but imo if you really wanna stay interested, play it MP!

reviewText:
This is probably the only review I've given for a game, and I've done so because I've never felt so ripped off in my life for buying this over-hyped POS.

I'll start the slow clap to CA for the fantastic marketing of this game. I've played since Medieval I, and was blown away with Rome I when it first came out. I think CA knew that a majority of their players felt the same way, and made Rome II to be something much more grander than the original with their siege of Carthage video and the new Rally Point teasers. I pre-ordered...and CA played me well I'll give them that.

I played through all the patches, but I think it's safe for all of the players to assume that nothing CA can do will bring back the immersion and strategy that the prior TW games brought to the table. I swear to you, I've never even bothered to look at the general's traits because they don't matter. They die before they become significant. All that matters is grinding them to commander, general, infantry commander II, and great leader and bringing them to your training" Providences to pump out level III gold units for the rest of your armies so that you can steam roll the AI. Rinse and repeat. I've played many factions
date: and every time Rome is annihilated very early before I can even fight them...in a game called Rome II. Seige AI? Ha...just send out your useless plebs to attack their ladder units
recommended: and then slaughter the rest of the army at your gates when they abandon their ladders. Battles? Just use your infantry line to hold the enemy (after you take their skirmishers out with your calvary) while your javelin units get at least 200+ kills and eventually lead to the route of the enemy unit. No real strategy at all. You can use a different faction
hoursPlayed: but the same strategy always works. You can't lose unless you purposely try to. The series has been dumbed down beyond belief.\n\nThis is probably the only time I felt like I was scammed into buying a game based on past reputation and hype. CA
voteText: for me
helpfulPercent: has lost all credibility. I'm not saying I won't play again (because there is nothing else out there like the TW games)
votesHelpful: but I'll be sure to buy a game after it's "Gold Package" with all the additions is on sale for $25 (being generous)
votesTotal: and the reviews for the game are above 8.0 out of 10 on the average. You'd be a fool not to do the same."

reviewText: If you are a Total War fan avoid this game at all cost. The bad release, held back content for DLC greed, and over all bad form are just what the forums are full of. 12 patches later some of the launch bugs are fixed but you cannot fix what's wrong with this game. The AI is totally scripted and although you can break the linear campaign play by avoiding most political shanghia from allies" you still get the same super stack factions that have to be scripted to do something stupid because they could just roll you off the map if they kept going. The building systems leave little to no variablity as you almost always need food and pub order just to build stuff. The the monetary system is so freakin ridiculously out of wack you end up with millions and have factions pleading for huge amounts of money for silly things just to spend down. A civil war that has no rhymn or reason just randomly pops. The combat is just blobs nothing like Rome 1 was. The AI cheats in several ways; not following the same economy as you
date: cavalry that has more moral than typical
recommended: ambushes when army was in clear sight...ect. Instead of the tactical battles that were the norm for this series you instead have a series of power ups that your generals "earn" so combat turns into a pause-fest unless you're quicker than snail snot ona hot day. They only difference in gameplay through difficulties are stat manipulations and nothing the ai does is situationally relative
hoursPlayed: hes just better....\nAll in all I knew the TW series was dying
voteText: I had thought Empire was it's death rattle. Sad to see it still spit up a few more titles before its collapse into this mindless arcade clicker. Thanks for the memories

reviewText:
Guide on how to Rome II:

Step 1: Decide to play the Grand Campaign
Step 2: Select the Roman faction
Step 3: Start researching economic techs. (You see if you have all the gold your enemies won't have any to raise armies with!)
Step 4: Disband all armies to ensure that no rebellions happen. (How can someone revolt when there is no army to back them?)
Step 5: Destroy all buildings (Buildings are expensive and there are much better free buildings)
Step 6: Wait until all the open building slots are taken by slums (This will give a place for the poor people to live, and there by, increasing public order.)
Step 7: Now that you've successfully quelled all possible public disruptions before they could happen, you can focus on the real problem, diplomacy!
Step 8: You see if you've followed step 2 correctly you should have all the gold by now, and the other factions will be jealous and want your gold, so simply give them all your gold!
Step 9: Now that the neighboring factions have all your gold they will want your territories as well, so you will need to allow them to take all your territories (This is to avoid any negative diplomatic relations")
Step 10: Victory for Rome!

This review was brought to you in part by: The Carthaginians"

reviewText:
This game displeased an entire generation of Total War fans. Of course those were the fans that I did not agree with at all. This game finally does the series justice by returning to its roots and becoming a strategy game again. Ever since Empire and Napoleon it has been a multiplayer that also had some strategy to it.

The added little gems make it much more fluid of a game and it stops the old problem of having to make 50 armies just to maintain order. Order is now about city and region mangement and no longer reliant on masses of troops.

The units are well expanded from the original and the seige part of the game especially is much improved. The bells and wistled have been stripped so it is not as pretty to look at any more. You have to read instructions and listings to learn your units and buildings etc...

It is an old fashioned war game for old fashioned war gamers like me. I play it with Steam offline because I don't want to be bothered while playing. I like it that much.

reviewText:
Though this games launch was absoulutely attrocious, the emperor edition fixes the majority of the problems. Though many problems are still prevalent which of course can be fixed with a few good mods. I have put in a good 200 hours into this game and I greatly reccomend this product.

Pro's
-Runs like a dream.
-Looks beautiful.
-Multiplayer battles are extremely intense.
-Great modding community.
-Great setting (Nothing feels as good as sacking Rome).
-Campaign is one of the best (A proper working Auto-Resolve button).

Con's
-Unit rosters are a bit lacking (Mods fix this).
-The Campaigns mid to late game becomes way too easy.
-Town battles (Auto-Resolving fixes this).
-Generals die like flies (4 turns per year mod fixes this).
-DLC Market is attrocious (You have to pay for Blood&Gore!!!)

reviewText: There's always that blue sunday when you just want to ♥♥♥♥ up the lives of 5 tribes, the Western Roman Empire and settle in North Africa. The razing to the ground-function is great, and as a player of the Total War series since day one, I can say this is by far the most difficult yet most entertaining one. Smart AI, a lot of strategic options and a great diplomatic menu. The only downside is that trade isn't worth jack ♥♥♥♥, and the tribute state option is almost irrelevant in a diplomatic way. Even if you have an army outside their last city, which is right about to fall, the still won't admit defeat, something Rome II was much more realistic about. Besides that, it just looks and plays great. 8/10

reviewText: Despite all the flak it took online immidiatly after its release, Total War Rome II in its current state is a good game.  Im not denying that it was utter unplayable crap when it first launched; it was unacceptably to launch the game in the buggy and unoptimized state it was in.  In the last 12 patches however, CA has not only eliminated most of the bugs but optimized the game superbly and released loads of free lc including entire new factions.  The single player campaign is long but rewarding but where Rome II really shines is when it is played with friends.  The multiplayer campaigns seem to have finally been freed from the prevelent gamebreaking desync issues and conquering the Ancient World with a friends is a blast.  The online battles are also surpurb, with a plethora of units to experiment with and maps to fight strategically on.  Also excellent is Rome II's extensive modding community.  With mods that enhance graphics to completly new campaigns mods give Rome II hundreds of hours of extra replayability. The only main flaw in Rome II is its horrendous naval combat.  Having gone an played the layered and realistic approach to naval combat in Napolean, Rome II's naval aspect is a step back for the series.  I frequently enountered glitches that caused two ships to simutaniously destory each other while ramming, ships that refused to board other ships, glitchy pathfinding, and graphical bugs that left chunks missing from the ship models.  As a person whose first Total war game was Rome II (although I've played many others since then) , Rome II is a game with good mechanics and excellent multiplyer that is only dragged done in its current state by minor (but irritating) bugs and the atrocious state of naval combat.  6.5/10

reviewText:
This is the coolest game I have every played... EVER!!!!!!!

Alright, passed my earlier uninspiring review of this game. Rome 2 to me is probably one of the best total war's to have come to the table, along with stunning graphics, immersing battles, and amazing campaign maps (that you see in every total war) it brings some other new cool things to the table (previously not seen in any total war's that I'm aware of).

The first Total War that I ever got the chance to play was empire, in which if you haven't played you should, I immediately was in love with everything from the gigantic map to the battles (a new concept of play in strategic games to me) but empire was lacking so much, whether it be the poorly designed technology advancement, or the lack of siege equipment, or even the sad diplomatic communications that certain other games like civilization 4 and 5 bring into play. Then I got to try out medieval and was immediately disapointed by the lack of ability to play through naval battles (although the family tree dealings was amazing). Clearly both of these games had things lacking and after playing through Shogun 2 and seeing the basic line of a map I was starting to think that total war games were just a swap of dissapointment, if one game had one thing that was awesome then it would lack something awesome from another game. Then total war rome came out and my faith suddenly came alive with it. Rome 2 finally offers the oppurtunity to bring in naval ships for player use, along with a land army to charge through the city streets (the results being rather destructive). The map is probably larger than any other I've ever seen and the political dealings have finally been patched with some beautiful details that I have been (silently) screaming for them to bring into the game, such as the use of satrapies previously only seen in medieval 2. The game also brings in the new multiple cities per-province" deal and makes war a more complicated prospect than just "army go here
date: city is mine" if you want a number of cites
recommended: taking just one of them could hurt you
hoursPlayed: due to if public order is low in one of the other ones (possibly owned by an enemy) you'll have a rebellion show up near your recently captured cities. There are tons more new prospects besides this
voteText: and all of them together provide a new feeling to the game that (again I say) was incredibly lacking.\n\nBUT! This game did still certainly have it's dissapointing faults that at first made this game unfun for me. Like the fact that your own family hierachy dealings were pitiful
helpfulPercent: basic at best. Or the fact that you can't move seperate army units without a present general to go boost a garrison. This bothered me so much in fact that the first time I wanted to make a review it was going to be negative. Thinking on it a little longer though (in terms of on the lack of ability to move army units without a general present) this actually properly complicates the game with a obstacle to overcome
votesHelpful: while also putting one in place for your enemies. Do you need a garrison boosted? Build a building to do so. And many of the basic family hierachy problems were fixed in this latest update adding "emperor edition""

reviewText:
I recommend this game
If you like chess, go, or risk you will as well

WARNING
IF YOU'RE SLOW, so is the game. IF YOUR COMPUTER IS SLOW, so is the game [with the exception of downloading certain graphical mods , deselecting the ability to view other player movement and using the advanced graphics option (at the top of the page under graphics, under options under the menu that comes up when you press the esc key)]

SUGESTION
Get it Now! while it's cheap, and if you are reading this when it isn't less than 30 dollars on steam get it another time while it's cheap and make sure you get it online in an area with a good internet speed and an ether net cord (cord for direct internet connection) because it's a pain in the you know where to download from a disc.  Spend money on the game the expansion packs seem worthless though with all the cool mods.  Play epic battles in campaign, limit the amount of time you spend on everything in the game, always make quick decisions while playing (in campaign and in battles) open another window before playing the game so you have the ability to multitask with the alt tab key between different things [if you don't but you want to multitask than you're screwed, (I like to play Rome while watching a movie with an HDMI cord and the projector function in the computer)].


MODS
Without certain mods Rome II may be unbearable for you, so don't invest large amounts of time into your first campaigns unless you know what you're doing.

SUGESTED GRAPHICAL MODS!!!

TREE REMOVAL MOD (best mod!! allows for much faster game play + looks more realistic (can boost other graphics like terain atroscopic and texture to get the best effect)

SPLENYI' BETTER CAMPAIGN CAMERA(MOD FRIENDLY) + CLOUD REMOVAL (the version you want just says cloud removal)

LITTLE SETTLEMENTS [(don't worry big cities still have big walls in battle) (first 4 mods listed go well together)]

EXTENDED CAMERA MINI MOD (you might like this and it might be the best thing ever for you or not)

No HDR mod [helps battle frame rate and again you might really like this but probably not (reduces light dynamics)]

a world to explore (simple mod that just makes sense, especially in the beginning of your first campaign)

2nd WARNING (mods)

Mods don't usually work unless installed before a campaign is launched

Mods don't always work together (although the graphical mods that I suggested I think work with
just about anything)

Mods that are old don't always work - these mods show a yellow triangle infront of them after downloading

Mods of a feather don't flock together (usually) [mod overloads=good but don't usually work together or with certain mods (This goes for unit mods as well)]


In General

THE GRAPHICAL MODS I CHOSE ARE MUST HAVES, BUT with campaign mods there are many ways to go and no right or wrong campaign mod to choose. It all depends on what you want to do. Depending on which faction you are you may want an Italian mod or a mod that develops major factions (these mods -- and there are many -- are highly recommended due to the fact that the campaign is never ending and almost dissatisfying at the end because of it) or mods specifically for certain factions (this is especially important for troop mods). But keep in mind that when you're just starting out you should test a few good unit mods for your specific faction, grab a serious overhaul mod [one that is comprised of multiple (3 to 6) mods]  make sure you have the graphics mods I mentioned and to get rid of view enemy troop movement and don't make the AI too easy or too hard just start out with normal or hard level of difficulty.

Just Remember

REMEMBER to hold down the clicker before releasing and sending a troop to somewhere that it will atrophy or into enemy territory sending a troop to enemy territory is extremely easy due to several occasional glitches in the game also

REMEMBER to close out of the little diplomatic window by pressing x before you click on the next faction otherwise you will think you’re on the next faction but you're really still on the same one additionally

REMEMBER to delete mercenaries after a battle the same turn you bought them and to only buy them on the turn of the battle because their upkeep is ridiculously expensive make sure you

REMEMBER public order and keep it in the green to do this

REMEMBER that when clicking on city details (a little circle that has a building in it) after clicking on the city that you can stop taxing a specific province by clicking the box in the top left corner that is checked when they are being taxed also

REMEMBER  that if you have enough built up public order or are still getting more public order you can increase or decrease your taxes by clicking on your treasury chest button (always at the bottom) and by moving the little red dot on the bar furthermore

REMEMBER your food and don't let there be a food shortage or your troops and city troops will atrophy and be extremely easy to take over this goes for public order to except instead of losing troops you'll receive more and more and more rebel troops after a certain number of turns that can be seen by hovering a mouse over the face that changes color to show public order that is visible on the left when the city is clicked on also

REMEMBER to create a strategy when you're researching tech don't just click something way down the line that you want but start by getting stuff that really good that only takes a couple or a few turns also try to pic things that are essential like I always like to research the technology that gets artillery first because they are essential for taking over capital cities and save you from having to fight battles against small annoying armies like rebels by destroying them long before they even meet your troops also artillery is useful in most fights

REMBER to have the infantry to guard them though and to keep a close eye on them so you can tell them to drop siege equipment and to then run away before enemy infantry or Calvary get them

REMEMBER that one of the best generals you can have are Calvary for almost all armies except in rare cases where you need a strong defensive infantry unit to help defend a city or something

REMEMBER to be nice to other factions but when they really want something -- no matter what make the pay up the wing wang for it -- by in the diplomacy box under the compass at the bottom of the screen and after selecting on a nation to negotiate with you press payments and chose to either give or demand money

REMBER to just select one and start dialing in a fare bargain the select the other box and the price asked for will carry over and if you have different incomes, which you always do, you will be able to go back and forth changing the dial until you find the perfect price and you should

REMEMBER to pick a price just below what it says is high so some where a little below high on moderate and this will get him to accept without rejecting you and will get you the best deal

REMEMBER in battles to use defensive formations and to have enouph room to move troops around and to flank and or surround a troop like you would in go also make sure you back your troops up like you would in chess and most importantly make sure you don't take risks to great like the ones you wouldn't like to do in a game of risk.

reviewText:
So, let me toss my hat into this ring.

Rome II released a fair bit buggy. AI was too aggressive against the player, but not each other. There was a weird glitch in Gameplay everyone complained about I never saw (And was fixed within the second week patch). When I first played it, it was funnish still, but all these new diplomacies out of reach due to overly bizarre AI was the main issue. Not so much anymore.

AI follows a state based on their relationship status to you, which is based on if you're war with their enemies (+) or with their friends (-) and follows a fairly sensible pattern, where someone at 150+ relations won't declare war on you unless you attack someone in that is their defensive alliance (But if they are afraid/good enough friends, they'll peace out fairly quickly.) Someone at -200 is undoubtly going to declare war on you, even if they have to launch a naval invasion to make it happen. The AI does get afraid though, The selecuids at war with everyone suddenly found Galatian Barbarians running rampant over their stuff, and they peaced out with a massive gold gift to avoid further destruction.

Combat AI is mostly good, especially in field battles. If your line is too short, they will flank you with their infantry. Sometimes they go with a lopsided strategy against your weak flanks to try to break them and sweep into the side. Cav will chase your archers round and round unless you counter them. They use scout cavalary to try to find your people if you hide in the forest rather than marching around aimlessly. Combat AI gets a little weird in city sieges. THey kind of understand how to defend, in that they'll move to fill gaps you break in the wall, defend the right areas, put archers to counter movements. Without siege weapons, you'll get punished trying to climb the walls. Attacking though it's a bit weird. First it'll move up ladders, and if that fails, they'll attack your gate (AI has siege gear, but never allowed it to get to my walsl before). Most of the time this still goes straight forwards, but this does allow your archers to pepper them freely, despite ladders on the walls. Though since the ladders appear to be made out of adamintine, that's probably for the best. Once trhough, they tend to just stream their entire force through. Archers, cavalry, infantry, everything.

Combat stats are pretty nice. Morale is still a big deal like Shogun 2, though even the most untrained levy is not nearly as much of a pansy as the Rise of the Samurai Levy units which would take one casualty and panic like the world is ending. Some morale seems a bit ridiclous (Killing 119 Thorax Swordsman in a group and yet the last one still fights on) but most respond to shocks like hard shock cav charges pretty well. Generals are important to maintain morale and their abilities are really helpful. They also have other bonuses that vary heavily, like reducing unit cost or improving everyone's skill, or reducing enemy morale. Army Groups now are permenant things that build traditions as well that outlive their generals and can be reinstated if they are wiped out. These can represent a key doctrine certain groups employ. Combat can get a bit slow and sloggy though when you have spears in defensive position and all they have are is spears. BRING A SWORD. Will admit, combining Shield strength into armor and missile accuracy into missle damage on the stat screen is a bit weird.

Campaign isn't like Rome 1 where Population is the only important stat and money is infinite. Population is still important, population growth allowing areas to gain new buildings to make more money. Money really varies though where you start. If you start as Parthia and take over Iran, that's a free money from the trade goods and Eastern bonus to towns (Local COmmerce bonus+10% bonus from Being Eastern.) Whereas Rome is very tempting to go full military, and you'll wind up bankrupting yourself in your war against Carthage, unable to pay for reinforcements and navies.

Campaign other nice note: Nobody plays that similar. Geography and unit types are nicea nd diverse. Now, some, like Parthia, play totally different from most others. Parthia plays like a Steppe Horde that got some full plate knights. They also get bonus damage on all their ranged weapons. Even after a 15% bonus, Rome's slingers and javs still do way less damage than parthians, and that's not mentioning the archers. Slinger: Normal 18, Parthia: 21. Jav: 39, Parthia 45, Archer: 27 Parthia: 32. Cretan archers of some hellenic factions have the 32, but those are a tier 3-4 unit. Parthias get those archers from a tier 2 building... that also ride horses. Rome has Legionaires. Sparta has a diverse set of units based aroudn their social stratifications, Athens has a few nice cavalry, Macedon with their units, Egypt with their mixture of native Egyptians and greek things, Pontus and Selecuids with mixture of eastern and hellenic, Galatia as he invading gauls. Lots of fun.

86%, Would recommend.

reviewText:
So, let me toss my hat into this ring.

Rome II released a fair bit buggy. AI was too aggressive against the player, but not each other. There was a weird glitch in Gameplay everyone complained about I never saw (And was fixed within the second week patch). When I first played it, it was funnish still, but all these new diplomacies out of reach due to overly bizarre AI was the main issue. Not so much anymore.

AI follows a state based on their relationship status to you, which is based on if you're war with their enemies (+) or with their friends (-) and follows a fairly sensible pattern, where someone at 150+ relations won't declare war on you unless you attack someone in that is their defensive alliance (But if they are afraid/good enough friends, they'll peace out fairly quickly.) Someone at -200 is undoubtly going to declare war on you, even if they have to launch a naval invasion to make it happen. The AI does get afraid though, The selecuids at war with everyone suddenly found Galatian Barbarians running rampant over their stuff, and they peaced out with a massive gold gift to avoid further destruction.

Combat AI is mostly good, especially in field battles. If your line is too short, they will flank you with their infantry. Sometimes they go with a lopsided strategy against your weak flanks to try to break them and sweep into the side. Cav will chase your archers round and round unless you counter them. They use scout cavalary to try to find your people if you hide in the forest rather than marching around aimlessly. Combat AI gets a little weird in city sieges. THey kind of understand how to defend, in that they'll move to fill gaps you break in the wall, defend the right areas, put archers to counter movements. Without siege weapons, you'll get punished trying to climb the walls. Attacking though it's a bit weird. First it'll move up ladders, and if that fails, they'll attack your gate (AI has siege gear, but never allowed it to get to my walsl before). Most of the time this still goes straight forwards, but this does allow your archers to pepper them freely, despite ladders on the walls. Though since the ladders appear to be made out of adamintine, that's probably for the best. Once trhough, they tend to just stream their entire force through. Archers, cavalry, infantry, everything.

Combat stats are pretty nice. Morale is still a big deal like Shogun 2, though even the most untrained levy is not nearly as much of a pansy as the Rise of the Samurai Levy units which would take one casualty and panic like the world is ending. Some morale seems a bit ridiclous (Killing 119 Thorax Swordsman in a group and yet the last one still fights on) but most respond to shocks like hard shock cav charges pretty well. Generals are important to maintain morale and their abilities are really helpful. They also have other bonuses that vary heavily, like reducing unit cost or improving everyone's skill, or reducing enemy morale. Army Groups now are permenant things that build traditions as well that outlive their generals and can be reinstated if they are wiped out. These can represent a key doctrine certain groups employ. Combat can get a bit slow and sloggy though when you have spears in defensive position and all they have are is spears. BRING A SWORD. Will admit, combining Shield strength into armor and missile accuracy into missle damage on the stat screen is a bit weird.

Campaign isn't like Rome 1 where Population is the only important stat and money is infinite. Population is still important, population growth allowing areas to gain new buildings to make more money. Money really varies though where you start. If you start as Parthia and take over Iran, that's a free money from the trade goods and Eastern bonus to towns (Local COmmerce bonus+10% bonus from Being Eastern.) Whereas Rome is very tempting to go full military, and you'll wind up bankrupting yourself in your war against Carthage, unable to pay for reinforcements and navies.

Campaign other nice note: Nobody plays that similar. Geography and unit types are nicea nd diverse. Now, some, like Parthia, play totally different from most others. Parthia plays like a Steppe Horde that got some full plate knights. They also get bonus damage on all their ranged weapons. Even after a 15% bonus, Rome's slingers and javs still do way less damage than parthians, and that's not mentioning the archers. Slinger: Normal 18, Parthia: 21. Jav: 39, Parthia 45, Archer: 27 Parthia: 32. Cretan archers of some hellenic factions have the 32, but those are a tier 3-4 unit. Parthias get those archers from a tier 2 building... that also ride horses. Rome has Legionaires. Sparta has a diverse set of units based aroudn their social stratifications, Athens has a few nice cavalry, Macedon with their units, Egypt with their mixture of native Egyptians and greek things, Pontus and Selecuids with mixture of eastern and hellenic, Galatia as he invading gauls. Lots of fun.

86%, Would recommend.

reviewText:
Rome II Emperor Edition is a great game.  Rome II is the best game that CA has made this far.   Easy learning curve.  The diplomatic concept is fine. Apart the missing family tree and the management weakness of the economy, Rome II, after a year  and some months, is now a great game that you must have.

reviewText:
At first, as you will know there were bugs, it was infested with them. Bad AI too.
Apart from the dull soundtrack (which can easily be fixed with the 4 part music mod) and the dull colour pallet (which there will be other mods for) it is a good game. I had to change the collision on mine because I hated this clustering going on, but it was not unbearable, it was just slightly irritating.
The good points are:
Few crashes, they only happen with lots of mods (55)
Best current AI on any total war to date. (It actually is)
Great campaign in most playthroughs, but can get too easy.

A few minor critisisms are the removed family tree (happy to see it making an appearence in Attila)
You have to have someone leading an army and you can't just select a few units, send them out to kill a few rebels and come home or have 3-4 units of light cav wandering around your borders to scout for enemy armies.
Lots of the units looks very similar their faces) and none really look majorly different. Voice acting is minimal, it could keep the game very fresh if people had different accents.
Cities never tend to look very different, barbarian cities are all the same, same with greeks and romans, same with eastern factions.
Characters feel expendable because they have no real meaning in your family, in Med 2 I would be both sad and scared when my King died, they usually had great influence in the world and my faction could easily fall apart after their death.


I think what makes this so good is the superb modding community. Champloo, Wolfman and many more who made me play this game. Overally it gets 60% good, though if I had not seen the majesty of Med 2 and Rome 1, it would probably get a higher mark. I just hope Attila can do better.

reviewText:
First let me say, I don't play the whole empire thing that much, I just do multiplayer battles with friends/interweb n00bs. So, at first, I was absolutely horrible at this game, but as I learned more about it, it became a really good game. Micromanagement is great. Keeping your calvary moving while making sure your infantry line isn't getting flanked is fun. Might not be too great the first hour or so though, you'll get absolutely smoked by everyone. Watch some videos on YouTube or something and get over the learning curve. Its a great game to play with friends.

Cons:
-You have to have a relatively decent PC if you want to play this. No ACER 300$ laptops, sorry. Not my choice. Lucky for me I'm able to get normal settings.
-Camera movement in my opinion struggles. I found the Classic Total War" camera setting or whatever and it was much better for me.
-AI sucks. Can't practice with AI to get prepared for human players. Humans will make a line and have calvarly on the outside. AI will bring generally the same units

reviewText:
Cross-platform: No.
Steam Trading Cards: Yes.
Platforms: Mac/PC
Single-player: Yes.
Multi-player: Yes.

I enjoy playing this game a lot especially in multi-player. Multiplayer is really fun to play with sieges, land battles, ambush, and coastal assault. I didn't enjoy single-player as much as the multi-player, but there is always a few people who are going to like it, wether you love single-player or multi-player.

This game isn't so great as Rome 1 was.
Reasons why

- 40% over budget

- Rome had realistic battles, it even achieved to be on documentaries, because of its realism in battles.

- Launch was a disaster.

- A few promises were made, yet some were not completed.

+ Nice graphics.

+ Nice gameplay.

- Graphical and performance issues.

- DLC Tactics removing factions from game for separate sale.

- Numerous A.I. Faults, Bugs & Glitches.

- Family Tree, Faction Politics are both Confusing & Downplayed.

+ Countless Factions & Units to field in battles.

+ Campaign Map Improvements ( Could have done better).

+ Cinematic Camera & Army Traditions

Would I recommend this game?
No
I would recommend rome 1 (Graphics are outdated), but if you want realistic battles that is the game for you.

reviewText:
What can i say I'm a long time player of the Total War series and after buying this game for $20 during the steam summer sale i can say this game disapoints greatly in comparison to Shogun 2. The whole squalor system is a major disapointment even in comparison to the Europa Universalis aggressive expansion system which was done materfully .. The Squalor or how to control it isn't even mentioned in the tutorial ... Sure the tactical battles can be fun if your units decide to listen to you , but the strategy mode is seriously lacking and can be frustrating, you find your self sitting for turns on end trying to put down revolts or trying to figure how to lower the squalor .... Overall if your looking for a great Strategy game go with Paradox and their Crusader Kings 2 / Europa Universalis games , they are way more fun , and eventhough they are more indepth/complex game , the learning curve and tutorial make things way easier and enjoyable. or the alternative stick to Shogun 2.....

I guess my only hope now for the Total War series is if Paradox buys them out , hehe

reviewText: The amount of haters and naysayers here is astonishing. Yeah, sure the game had to be patched up due to bugs. Sometimes the AI doesn't make good moves and ends up undoing itself. reviewText:
Competitive turn-based strategy game incorporated with real-time strategy. Sets an entirely different setting than any other Total War game so far. The combat experience is great because it's fairly balanced out and requires a lot of concentration.

Pros:
- Very realistically refined historical accuracy of units.
- Great open field combat and mechanics.
- Turn-based strategy can be quite difficult.
- Amazing mod community.
- O.K. co-op multiplayer.

Cons:
- AI is stupid. Could of been made more tactical to increase difficulty instead of being so heads-on agressive.
- Graphics are fairly demanding, and evenso when setting up high graphics doesn't meet marketing screenshot quality.
- The Total War encyclopedia for this game is just horrid in comparison to Shogun 2's.
- Political system could of been more like Shogun 2.

I've spent a lot of time playing this game right from the start. I pre-ordered it and really looked forward to it. People complained from the start, mentioning errors throughout gameplay and the game being very glitchy. I personally felt like they publisher literally released a beta. Honestly, many issues didn't start bugging me until later. The game remained very competitive but it could have had some improvements. Overall I always just turned a blind eye to the issues and the game remained very enjoyable, as I've experienced no different with CA in a positive way. All bugs and glitches were fixed very quickly.

Imagine playing Risk table-top but with enhanced 3D aesthetics, and when in combat instead of throwing dices you just get into real-time strategy which can possibly involve multiple armies and AIs depending on the conflict scenario. The game is very immersive and drags you right into the historical sphere mainly due to how all the units function and what abilities they bring to the field. The units for each faction are very refined in terms of what purpose they served in the days of old; what weapons and armour they carry onto the field.

The experience is very detailed from first-person camera tracing to follow units into a heads-on charge (as seen in trailers) to the morale boosts commanders provide to their battalion as they are near forfeit.

The game is very competitive and remains challenging and remains so throughout dozens of hours of play up into the hundreds, due to how every faction has its own types of units. You can literally just model your army's organizational structure after how they functioned in reality, or run experimental tests of your own, and this alone makes every battle a surprise. Fighting other factions will require you to adapt your armies.

On top of that there's the economical elements brought to the game, aswell as political intrigue, each different factors that can change the outcome of a war.

To end with the negative things; the AI could be better. Armies often just attack in small stacks, making it very easy to be victorious, sometimes not even posing a challenge. When you increase difficulty, armies just receive combat modifiers. They don't really become any harder to fight strategically. They don't grow 'smarter'. Even on high difficulty the AI is stupid, such as how siege battles are very boring. While provided with siege weaponary, you can basically just go stand in front of your gate with one unit and wait until they break through, only to see them try to push you aside instead of fight you or face you on multiple flanks. They just perform suicide missions and you can easily fight off an army of 3000 men with just two-hundred spears.

The graphics are great, although fairly demanding. You'll require a good processor and memory to render all the units in the field, although performance of the game has been significantly improved through later patches mainly in regards to units moving on the field, which in the past could happen through lag spikes. - High graphics don't par with the screenshots marketed.

The encyclopedia is very bad. It's hard to find certain elements of the game for more information, if you don't have the ability to right-click elements in a unit roster. The search function is just horrid because it doesn't let you find anything that would even bring you to using the encyclopedia in the first place.

I feel the political system could be better such as having the old family tree from Shogun 2. It gives your faction an individual touch, while having an avatar as your faction leader doesn't really mean anything. They are only displayed as portraits in the diplomacy window wherein they will have some generic dialogue. Their appearance is very generic, while for Shogun 2, each faction had unique daimyo's (clan leaders) that didn't look like your everyday general. You don't really grow a bond with the characters in your political system anymore, and wont care much for the political intrigue, because all the characters and armies are, are stats. At one point somebody may assassinate your Hannibal Barca, but two turns later another with the same name is added to your pool.

reviewText:
Total War: Rome II is a recommend, but with certain caveats. Rome II was a mess at release. With each patch it's gotten better, and the form it's in now is well worth having and playing. That being said, it's still nowhere near what the promotional materials and videos showed in the lead-up to the game's release, so it still feels like a little bit of a letdown from what we were hoping for.

Anyway, if you're at all familiar with total war games, you know the gist of it: turn based strategic map, realtime tactical battles. Both types are solid for the most part, but marred by somewhat stupid AI depending on the circumstances. If you're not, a little more detail: Total War games are effectively two games in one. There is a turn-based campaign map where you build settlements, recruit armies, and move them around to strategically useful locations, as well as a real-time tactical map where your armies battle with other armies (which can be optionally skipped via an auto-resolve function) to fight one another. It is my personal opinion that this is the best strategy series on the market, and while Rome II is not the best offering in the series, following the patches since release it has ended up being a competent entry in that series.

Beyond that, I feel that I should take a moment to rail on Sega for their terrible DLC policy. The DLC is way overpriced, and limiting Sparta and Athens behind a paywall, in particular, is just ridiculous. Let alone the Blood and Gore" DLC which was free in previous entries.

So anyway
date: yeah - recommend for the core game (which is only likely to increase as it continues to be patched and improved)
recommended: but huge lack of recommendation for the DLC on a value perspective."

reviewText:
Diplomacy! I have played many games in the Total War series. This is the first one (IMO) that allows you to deploy diplomatic strategy with good effect. This really gives you a new way of planning your expensionism.

E.g. 1) I make strong allies, help them in war. Though they have a city I need for my region. By creating unrest with agents I get the city to rebel and I conquer without damaging.
E.g. 2) When I have no intention to spread further in a certain direction (north), I help a local faction by teaming up and target (that's an option now) adjecent territories. I reinforce while he leads the attack. This way I gain a very appreciative friend, with a territory that closes my border (like a buffer). Now I can fully dedicate my forces south

reviewText: I love all of the Total War series. That being said, this one feels less like a Total War game and more of an arcade game. I do like the new combat system they implemented for cavalry, adding true weight to their charges - thereby making them useful in the game unlike the older series. However, the battles do not last anywhere near as long, the games campaign feels childish, and the management of your country feels like it's been simplified to the point where a person with an IQ of 79 could accomplish victory in this game... Which seems to be a common theme in long-running series.\n4/5

reviewText:
Let me start by admitting that Rome II was launched before it was ready. Because of this, it experienced a rocky start and brought out the Rome II haters in full force.

However, CA has worked hard by patching these issues as quickly as possible. I can honestly say that the game now runs EXTREMELY good on my computer and displays unrivaled graphics excellence in a turn based strategy game. Rome II is revolutionary in the Total War series by giving you much larger cities to fight in and the addition of amphibious landings which are nice additions to the series. I own every Total War game besides the first Shogun, and therefore have been fortunate enough to watch this series get better and better with every release. Conquring the known world never gets old! Rome II is unrivaled in its abilty to give you an awesome turn based empire building game and ALSO include beautifully rendered battles. When you attack or defend against a rival army, Total War games give you the ability to be the general on the battlefield and lead your troops to victory personally!

Rome II also has a great modding community that allows you to play the game just about any way you choose! Rome II battles are a little unrealistic in the speed at which units move and the fact that transport ships are almost as strong as actual war ships I wish it would be slowed down a bit, and more strength given to warships, but there are plenty of realistic mods that do this for you. The Steam Workshop makes it easy to install and use these mods. CA does a great job balancing this game, but again takes away some realism because of this. Roman units are not as tough as they were in real life, but again there are mods that can fix this for you.

I LOVE this game, and am always excited when I have time to play! Keep up the good work CA!!!
Long live the Republic!

SPQR

reviewText:
Let me start by admitting that Rome II was launched before it was ready. Because of this, it experienced a rocky start and brought out the Rome II haters in full force.

However, CA has worked hard by patching these issues as quickly as possible. I can honestly say that the game now runs EXTREMELY good on my computer and displays unrivaled graphics excellence in a turn based strategy game. Rome II is revolutionary in the Total War series by giving you much larger cities to fight in and the addition of amphibious landings which are nice additions to the series. I own every Total War game besides the first Shogun, and therefore have been fortunate enough to watch this series get better and better with every release. Conquring the known world never gets old! Rome II is unrivaled in its abilty to give you an awesome turn based empire building game and ALSO include beautifully rendered battles. When you attack or defend against a rival army, Total War games give you the ability to be the general on the battlefield and lead your troops to victory personally!

Rome II also has a great modding community that allows you to play the game just about any way you choose! Rome II battles are a little unrealistic in the speed at which units move and the fact that transport ships are almost as strong as actual war ships I wish it would be slowed down a bit, and more strength given to warships, but there are plenty of realistic mods that do this for you. The Steam Workshop makes it easy to install and use these mods. CA does a great job balancing this game, but again takes away some realism because of this. Roman units are not as tough as they were in real life, but again there are mods that can fix this for you.

I LOVE this game, and am always excited when I have time to play! Keep up the good work CA!!!
Long live the Republic!

SPQR

reviewText:
I started playing Rome 2 in March of 2016, I read that at launch it was a mess, but by now it is pretty stable, at least to me, as a new player of Rome 2 who didn't experience its begginigns, I'm yet to find bugs or problems like crashes (none in the 57 hours of gameplay I have at the time of writing this review).

I have been playing the original Rome, and Medieval 2 for some time now, those were my first 2 total war games, and I love them, but I'm fastly getting close to equal the hours I have put to those games playing Rome 2, and that is because I find this game very different to them, yet, amazing.

First thing I noticed before buying this game, was the ammount of DLC it has, and a lot of them are just ridiculous to be sold as such, like the Greek culture pack and blood. Blood, as a DLC, and not as a graphical option, really? Nevermind, I payed for those 2 on sale, and I will get most of the rest when they are on sale again, NEVER on the normal price, because I don't support what SEGA is doing here.

Another thing I noticed that is different from the original Rome and Medieval 2, is the workshop integration. You can find some amazing mods made by the community, from small ones to improve your gameplay and experience, textures to improve graphics, and complex yet high quality overhauls like Divide et Impera.

Like I have been saying, this game is really different from the other 2 I mentioned, it took me a little while to get used to the new system of conquest and managing cities, and now I'm loving it, and the battles are improved as well, that nice feeling you get when using the cinematic camera while charging to your enemy is just priceless.

I recommend this game, I don't support what SEGA did here, again, but the game in itself is great. If you can, get it on sale, because the DLC is just not worth the whole price, I just whish this evil market strategy changes in the future.

reviewText:
Total War Rome 2 is an incredibly great turn based and real time strategy game.
You have multiple possible game modes.
1.) Scenario
You start with certain countries and have to reach certain goals in a limited amount of time.
2.) Sieges & battles
You can play set up fights / set up your own fights against another army.
3.) Single Player
No rules, just you and the world. You can choose between a lot of different starting countries.
4.) Multi PLayer
No rules, just you, your friend and the world.

The game splits up into 2 sectors. First, the world map where you can build citys, recruit armies, move them around, conquer other cities, use diplomacy, trade [...]. Then there is the RTS part - once you encounter an enemy you can choose to auto-fight him or fight him yourself. If you choose to fight the enemy yourself you are thrown onto the battlefield and can start setting up your units & get ready to fight.

The game does a lot of things right, and only a few wrong. The world map, the city-building, the diplomacy, everything is incredibly cool and well done. The RTS fights are challenging and its awesome to win a battle against a huge army with a small amount of units - simply because you used inferior tactics and unit controllings.

The very few downsides are the very long AI turns and the loss of RTS once you start having a huge empire. Later in the game its Quantity > Quality and you managing the units yourself and taking the fight into your own hands is getting unnecessary.

Overall, i fully recommend Total War: Rome II. You can play a lot of different countries, have endless fights with other empires and spend countless of hours building up your empire. 8/10

reviewText:
After a horrible launch The CA has failed to deliver the most basic requested features and instead went all out on the DLC whoring, 3 campaigns @ 15 euros each, and a ♥♥♥♥♥on of smaller dlc's that add units and factions.
Now call me old fashioned but I prefer to unlock factions through skill, as in having to grind to wipe out factions to be able to play with them instead of having to fork over some cash YET AGAIN to play what should have been in the base game.
As if that wasn't enough, they actually have the nerve to charge you 7.50 to be able to play Sparta & on top of that 15 to have a campaign that focusses on sparta, things like this are the reason that after 14 years I'm done with total war series.
If a company can be so low as to knowingly leave out features (family tree) just to force old school fans of the series to purchase the reskinned version (atilla) while forcing them yet again to either pre-order or pay extra to get access to day 1 DLC then I do not feel the need to pay for their games anymore, sure i'll give the cracked copy a try, but i'm pretty sure i'll delete it within an hour just like I did with Rome 2.

reviewText: After playing this game for a few hours, I can easily say this game is not up to par to the orignal Rome: Total War, or any Total War game I have played, and I have pladey almost all of the. I went into Rome 2 expecting Rome 1 with updated visuals, better enemy AI, better UI, and a few other minor tweaks here and there. I can say strongly that this game does none of the above beside updated visuals. The UI was the worst of them all here. The Orignal Rome had ease of access menus that you could clearly understand what they do, now the help pages take you to a wiki page, instead of being in the game. I constantly find myself at a loss at what to do, I cant tell what the units are that im recruting, I can tell what building are, much less do. The only good thing to come out of Rome 2 is that there are more factions, and that was instantly put down because you have to buy DLC to get them. In short, this is the worst Total War game Ive played, if you want a good game, get the orignal Rome, or even Medival 2, but whatever you do, DO NOT get this Total War

reviewText:
My biggest complaint having played since Shogun is that the units bonuses make no sense what so ever.

Italian Spearmen are by far the most OP units in the game, and can't be beat by melee specific infantry units.  Little to no tactics involved with the combat compared to original total war in which certain units benefitted significantly from fighting specific units with weaker stats or weaknesses.

Sea combat is very boring, can very easily win just about every battle with fire or ramming over and over as AI doesn't know how to compensate.

Graphics are fantastic, visual effects are great, but game play overall is lack luster.  Would not recommend spending the money on it until its no more then $20 if that.

reviewText:
This Game is a mixed bag. Let's start with the bad thing. They are: the AI, which is very bad.... they tried to fix it but still is not good enough. Units during combat become chaotic and in turns in to a massive cluster f**k. The game had some performance problems but I have played it today again and it run very smooth on high settings (My rig is 3570k OC, EVGA 660ti 2gb, 8gb 1600 RAM CL9). The good thing about this game is... the scale. There is nothing like fighting with 3000 Romans versus a horde of 7000 barbarians. It also innovates from the previous iterations of Total War. It adds features like Land and Naval combat on one map. It has some limited politics but not as in depth as Crusader Kings 2. Overall I hated this game when it came out but the recent patches seem to have addressed most of the issues and now I found myself playing for 8h strait. I don't know much about multilayer as I haven't spent much time playing it. I don't like the fact that they put soo much DLC out for example they knew that people will want to play as Sparta so they decided to charge for it. If you are a fan of games like Crusader kings 2 or Civ 5 only buy this game if you miss the lack of advanced combat.
Thank You for reading this review.
It is my first review and I hope I can make more in the future.

reviewText: Brand new to the game, but I actually kindof like it. Granted, I have not played RTWI or anything else in the Total War series. However, Total War as a whole is very interesting. The biggest downside for me personally is crashing and replay glitches. As mentioned, this game has some serious bug problems. It also crashes (for me) unpredictably. EDIT: Crashing seems to have been fixed in the last update\n\nIn terms of gameplay (I assume the whole Total War series works this way), it feels like a hybrid between Civilization and Age of Empires. Like Age of Empires, you can command your troops on the battlefield and organize formations in real time (except even better: you can pause it offline! Drives me crazy in Age of Empires!). Like Civilization, you can persue diplomacy, setup trade, and manage military positions from one province to the next in turn-based campaign. There are a few elements which really cannot be compared to either. Cinematic camera and inter-character communication is one of them. It does really feel like something from the movies. This game is probably even more combat dependant than Age of Empires, and far more combat dependant than Civilization. You are pretty much forced to wage wars of expansion, not just sit back on your haunches and make the world your friend. In Age of Empires it is theoretically possible to win by creating a wonder and develop such a powerful defensive network that few dare attack, and those who do suffer (I have never seen it happen except VS AI). In Civilization (AI games, I can't do online for some reason), you can use science, diplomacy" (i.e. monopoly on city state puppets)
recommended: just as long as you have a significant military to intimidate the opposition. In RTWII
hoursPlayed: you pretty much have to take stuff over as part of the overall victory condition.\n\nI have to say
voteText: I have never played anything quite like it. A very interesting franchise
helpfulPercent: when it works.\n\n[I am not going to give it a /10 rating
votesHelpful: because I have no idea what it would be]"

reviewText:
While this game has gotten a lot of outrage by the community who bought it on day one, I have yet to experience anything completely gamebreaking that hasn't been patched.
If you were a fan of the original Rome, you may be a little underwhelmed at first, but late game, like most total war games, is a bit of a chore to finish, but it still provides a lot of fun all throughout it.
If you haven't played the first Rome, play it first before playing this, but this is still a deserving sequel to an amazing game.

Edit:
After not playing this game for a long time, I still enjoy playing it. Not nearly as much as I've enjoyed other total war titles, but still a solid game, especially after all the patches. The release was underwhelming and unacceptable, which is sadly becoming more of an industry standard. Many people have already said this, but instead of releasing a game when it's supposed to, but is not enjoyable either due to bugs or in Rome 2's case, fundamental game changes, do what valve does and release it later. At any rate, the point of playing a game is to have fun, and so far, it is meeting that expectation.

reviewText:
I really wanted to like this game.

I was a big, big fan of Rome 1, and really enjoyed Empire TW too. However, this is just not as good as the original Rome. It feels like for every step forward graphically, there has been a step back in gameplay terms.

The family tree is missing, robbing the game of character and your attachment to particular units, so the armies are just pieces on a board. You can now only move an army if a general is in command, which is overly restrictive. Also, most annoyingly, the distance from which reinforcements can join a battle is immense! I believe armies from within the province a battle is taking place can join it as a reinforcement. As some provinces are huge, this feels particularly silly. That army from across a mountain range about two screens away you forgot about? Well, tough, if it is in the same province you can expect to see it advancing upon your position in a few minutes.

Odd and average.

reviewText: This game is a fine example of the classical stuggles that occured before the Pax Romana. It also shows the passing time with uses of the older Roman tri-line formations consisting of; Hastati, Principes, and Triarii, while also including the later Marion reforms with the induction of the modern uniform legions. While I love Rome this game does have it's faults. I would give this game a 7/10. It introduces new and cool things but it is not as polished as Shogun 2. There are many bugs and frustrating gliches in this game which makes it very hard to enjoy. Also ♥♥♥♥ Oathsworn. They are the strongest unit in the game in my opinion. Theu have extremely good stats overall but they have a ridiculously high melee defence making them all but unkillable in close combat. Great Job

reviewText:
This review was written after 400h of gameplay and 8 pathces.

Rome II: Total War is the sequel of the original Rome: Total War, released in 2004. If you have not played the the original, and you like Real-Time Strategy games, then you will like Rome II. If you have already played the original game or the other Total War games (Medieval, Shogun, Empire), then you'll probabily hate the sequel.
For those who are new to the Total War series, I will briefly explain the game: Rome II: Total War is a strategy game about conquering lands and building an empire, using diplomacy, trade, agents and, of course, war. You control one nation, with its own strengths and weaknesses. There are two main moments in this game: the campaign map (turn-based) and the battlefield (real-time). The campaign map displays settlements and cities throughout the lands and armies and fleets, and when it is your turn you may chose where to send your forces, to engage diplomacy or improve the buildings in the cities you own (wich can provide benefits such as better soldiers or more income for your treasure). Once you decide to attack an enemy force or city (or if a enemy attacks you in its turn), you switch to the battlefield. In the battlefield, you will deploy an army composed by the forces you had in the camapign map and then fight your enemy in a real-time battle. You control battalions instead of individual soldiers, and must watch for their morale, numbers and how tired they are and use wisely your soldiers. After the battle is over, you switch back to the campaign map and the forces involved in the battle advance or retreat accordingly to the outcome of the battle.

Good features and improvements

Rome II: Total War added important features to the previous Total War games.
The first is the Army Instances: you may issue orders to your armies use forced marches, travelling faster but being easely ambushed, to build defesive positions, being unable to move but gaining defensive bonuses or to loot the land, advancing slowly but earning money.
The provincial system bounds smaller settlements to large ones, making all ot them share bonueses from buildings. Also, you can issue Edicts to provinces you control entirely, giving bonueses to achieve specific goals (better income, faster recruitment or improved public order).
Public order has a index that goes from 100 (very happy) to -100 (the province rebels), and it is more realistic than the previous system in which it took two turns to a perfectly happy city go berserk after a minor change in taxes.
There is a large variety of units. Balkanic spearmen, Iberian spearmen and Arabian spearmen look different from each other, which increases the perception that you are in a vast world inhabited by many different cultures.
Amphibious battles are certainly one of the better improvements: ships fight in the sea while armies clash on the land. Artillery ships can bombard a city's towers and a vessel full of legionaries can disembark to aid their allies in mainland, or even disembark directly inside a enemy port to capture the city.
Last and least, the game is truly beautiful and you'll watch one of the most realistic graphics in the market.

Bad features and what was left behind

Many important features from previous games were stripped in Rome II: Total War.
There is no more family tree, which displayed your faction leader's family. Even if it seems a useless feature, it greatly improved immersion in the game. Without it, your generals became uninteresting characters.
The game is corrupted with bugs: aside from graphical issues and good computers being unable to maintain a steady rate of FPS, the game crashes too often.
The game was extremely streamlined: the buildings options are shallow, characters have few and uninteresting traits (in Rome I, a general could have dozens of traits that reflected the path of their lifes), transport ships spawn instantly making fleets near useless, siege battles are almost worthless playing (in fact, many siege battles now do not even include walls...) and all agents (Spies/Dignataries/Veterans) do basically the same thing (assassinate, slow enemy forces or slow down construction in enemy cities).
Units in the battlefield now possess arcade abilities. On exemple: many spearmen have a speed boost ability that enhance charges. It seems ok at first, but why spearmen? Can't a Roman legionary run faster for a while? Some abilities like a form phalanx" or "form shieldwall" should be
recommended: availabe to pikemen and soldiers carrying shields
hoursPlayed: but generic abilities like "run faster" should not be "active skills"
voteText: but "passive skills" available to whoever can run faster. In Medieval 2: Total War
helpfulPercent: if cavalry had enough space to run
votesHelpful: they would deliver a devastating charge
votesTotal: but in Rome II: Total War heavy cavalry simply have the "devastating charge" button. Arcades abilities such as "run faster" or "improved charge" kill the realism that was supposed to be the most remarkable feature of Total War.\nAI has never been anything close to clever in previous Total War games

Conclusion

Rome II: Total War is a good game. It is beautiful. It is huge. But it is not what the community was expecting

reviewText:
Now I know that I am writing this review a bit late since the release of this game. That being said, I do have a few things to say that have probably been said already. Rome II is the not long awaited sequel to Rome: Total War and though the game has been created in a era where better game mechanics can be made and better graphics can be created, The Creative Assembly has not made very many improvements to the original game. Many of the changes that you will see in this game will be in the campaign section, where TCA has decided to put much of their work on by making it simplistic as possible, and while I see that they are trying to expand their audience by making the UI of the game much easier, it ends up becoming a flop since they make it too simplistic. By making it too simplistic, you as the player cannot make very many changes to a specific provience and even finding the problem for the specific region can be difficult.

Another problem that is in the game is the AI, and even though TCA has created so many game in the Total War series, they still have not tackled the bad AI issue. Much of the AI in the game is terrible, both in the battles and in the campaign section, on the campaign side the AI might put up some fighting chance in the beginning of the game but when you actually gain a large empire the game does not become fun due to the fact that the AI does not form any sort of coalition or federation to destroy you and you can just simply steamroll though the entire game by attacking them one by one. Also the balancing of the AI in the campaign map is certainly a huge problem, as the faction of the Roman Empire can easily be crushed by a single northern barbarian tribe or the mighty Egyptian empire can be destroyed by a random faction from west Africa, and many of the AI is very stubborn when diplomacy comes into play, when a large portion of the factions will not have any contact with you unless  you give them several thousand gold coins.

As long as it has been in the Total War series, the battle AI has always been a considerability huge issue where TCA has never seemed to fix over each game. Various bugs and problems always seem to riddle the game where the AI will never play smart and most of the time will try to rush straight forward towards you or the units will stay in place regardless if you are on the defending side. The bugs in the game make the units might even just walk into walls or just run in circles, which saddens me because these problems are never fixed or are patched" way too late in advance. As usual besides problems on land
date: the sea battles are just as awkward as ever as units sail through the land or cannot keep a single formation straight and even sail around the place just to board a ship that is right in front of them. The sieges in the game are an issue as well as the one centerpoint in its past games have been scraped and multiple points have been put in place where you have to defend from multiple sides. So in retrospect
recommended: instead of consolidating your forces into one last stand
hoursPlayed: you have to divide them up into two or three groups to fend off oncoming attackers
voteText: which is annoying and frustrating to me. *Side Note: When on the offensive side
helpfulPercent: throwing sticks at a gate is not a logical way to take it down!*\n\nAs much as I could rant about the game there is only a small handfull of things that I could say that is a good thing about it. The graphics of Rome II do look beautiful and makes the landscape and its nearby cities look amazing
votesHelpful: as well as the look of the soldiers but unfortunately it does make the game lag alot and makes load times unbearable. Another good thing about the game is it's expansive campaign map
votesTotal: where there are at least over a hundred proviences that you can take over which makes you feel like that you are creating a empire
votesFunny: which is nice since in other games (besides Empire Total War) you feel like the world map is very small and condensed.\n\nThough I could go on and on about the bad (and very few good things) about Rome II I feel like I have spoken enough about this game. Even though TCA will patch their game to fix many multiple problems and bugs
commentsCount: continuing to release games with a poor polish and huge problems will not help the Total War series in the long run. It is sad to see such a great series crumble like the fall of the Roman Empire
column16: but if TCA continues to make these games in this terrible of state then the longevity of the series is doomed."
